alfredsnippet.snippet:
Etienne Klein & Marc Lachi√®ze-Rey, The Quest for Unity - The Adventure of Physics, p.85

"It seems that every practitioner of physics has had to wonder at some point why mathematics and physics have come to be so closely entwined. Opinions vary on the answer ... Bertrand Russell acknowledged ... 'Physics is mathematical not because we know so much about the physical world, but because we know so little.' ... Mathematics may be indispensable to physics, but it obviously does not constitute physics."
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - Physics is Mathematical Not Because We Know So Much About the Physical World, But Because We Know So Little
